author: thiago_crowdtainer
content: 100% agree with this. "Zeroism" of bugs or perfectionism *in the newer EL clients* + using this to artificially slow down the merge dates doesn't help anybody IMO; Correct me if I'm wrong, but given that the current minority EL clients *remain* minority at the time of the merge (highly likely simply because they are 'new'), bugs specific to them wouldn't cause slashings for the users of these new clients, and such users can easily switch to another client in case of bugs, then go back once the bug is solved.  Over time, as the newer EL clients gain more market share (as they mature and get battle-tested), then they naturally become more critical in sense of "being free of bugs" - but today IMO their value add is really the extra optionality for stakers.  This might be controversial, but IMO Ropsten proved the network as a whole is ready to go, and we should skip having Goerli + Sepolia as a "pre-requisite" to go mainnet as its causing a lot of extra work with little added value (e.g., instead of new ELs spending time fixing the last issues, time needs to be devoted coordinating all the testnet transitions). The whole point of having multiple clients is that its okay and expected to have a few issues, *especially* in the case of a minority client..

author: ryanleeschneider
content: ^ IMO the best counter argument to this is that every bug fixed in _any_ client is _potentially_ a bug that exists in _every_ client.  Also sometimes the majority client has a bug that's not found until a minority client implements the same functionality and gets different results.

author: timbeiko
content: The Merge is also the best opportunity we'll have to make progress on EL client diversity given it requires all stakers to run one. If we have a majority client on the EL, the same risks exists as on the CL, where a bug could lead to the wrong chain being finalized and be very painful to unwind. If we can get geth below 2/3rd of validator nodes at the merge, that's very valuable. Good explainer here: https://dankradfeist.de/ethereum/2022/03/24/run-the-majority-client-at-your-own-peril.html

author: syentist.

Basic project management suggests they should be tackled serially, not concurrently
